doc.field: This collection contains roughly 400 black and white photogrphs pertaining to student anti-war protests in the 1960s and early 1970s. The majority of these photographs relate to student anti-war protest in the United States, but several also relate to foreign protests and other general anti-war protests in the United States, most notably the Poor People's Campaign of 1968. Other notable topics covered in this collection include protests at San Francisco State University Protests and University of California Berkely, and the "Stop the Draft" demonstration led by pacifics Linda Morse.

Paul Cronin (1972, London) is co-founder of Sticking Place Films, a production and distribution company in London. His films include Look out Haskell, It's real!, The Making of Medium Cool (2001), Film as a Subversive Art: Amos Vogel and Cinema 16 (2003), and In the Beginning was the Image: Conversations with Peter Whitehead (2006). He is also the editor of several books on the film industry, including Herzog on Herzog and Alexander Mackendrick's On Film-Making: An Introduction to the Craft of the Director. Cronin is currently he working on A Time to Stir, an historical documentary about the student protests at Columbia University in 1968, set to be released in 2018.
Donated in 2013 by Paul Cronin. The accession number associated with this gift is 2013.042.
No materials were separated from this collection.
